flow.descriptionCdata:
6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.0dd4afab-eeb9-468d-ab33-98f78a06c704.prompt=SasHostPasswordPrompt\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.1631be1d-9730-43ee-a345-a84a16e83ad7.prompt=Username\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.19b0f7b4-e13d-4041-b9ba-4549873f4419.prompt=Kill the process forcefully? 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.2d6135ea-484b-47fa-b0bb-6761072adef9.prompt=Host\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.2fb862c2-60d0-4a98-8081-c3bfd61d5e43.prompt=PrivateKeyFile\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.30a0e8fe-eac4-4715-bc2c-4968b04a1b11.prompt=SasHost\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.35607478-e23a-4b1d-b331-eb2d28db8d40.prompt=SasHostUsername\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.45249171-d4ea-486f-8fec-f73d0f79fbef.description=
Checks to see if a string matches a specific rule.

If the matchType is RegEx, input matchTo is the regular expression like \: ^-?\d+(([\.,]\d+)?)+$. Input toMatch is the actual string to check to see if it matches the matchTo expression.

Inputs\:
matchType - The type of match to perform.
toMatch - The string to check if matches another string.
matchTo - The string to match against. 
ignoreCase - Boolean value for whether or not to ignore case during match.

Responses\:
success - The String matched.
failure - The string did not match, or something went wrong.
6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.529a20e0-651e-49fc-83b9-e4c9e39c594b.prompt=Password\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.57e8a30e-7cd3-4343-9584-29113aa96023.prompt=Pty\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.71cc1b86-9786-40d6-9dee-82fa5fceafce.description=
Checks to see if a string matches a specific rule.

Inputs\:
matchType - The type of match to perform.
toMatch - The string to check if matches another string.
matchTo - The string to match against.
ignoreCase - Boolean value for whether or not to ignore case during match.

Responses\:
success - The String matched.
failure - The string did not match, or something went wrong.
6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.8924a9d9-7718-498c-ab25-fe67ca79b8c9.prompt=PasswordPrompt\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.8fa6bb20-9106-4cdf-b9f1-6dea8db2969b.prompt=Port\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.9d975f2b-9ef9-48f8-abbb-706d272d08cf.prompt=OutputPath\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.b7ff80dc-0b8f-4d4a-bf43-789148076d99.description=
Runs a command and allows user to specify that it runs locally (in this case no port should be specified), via ssh, Global Shell, ROSH, Telnet, or RSH.

Inputs\:
host - hostname or ip address
port - port number for connecting to the host
username - username to connect as
password - password
protocol - the protocol used to run the command (can be one of ssh, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, local, or NASConnectTelnet)
timeout - (optional, default 90 seconds) time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete
command - the command to execute
arguments - the arguments to pass to the command
environment - specifies environment variables/values that need to be defined when running command
startDir - the path to the starting directory
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty
privateKeyFile - The absolute path to the private key file for remote host.
sasHost - the host we want to run the ROSH command on
sasHostUsername - the username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost
usernamePrompt - the prompt that when seen should send the username; used by the Telnet protocol; when used by the NASConnectTelnet protocol, the default value is 'NAS Login\:'
passwordPrompt - the prompt that when given should send the password; used by the Telnet protocol; when used by the NASConnectTelnet protocol, the default value is 'Password\:'
outputPath - network accessible path used by the operation to store temporary files. If not specified it points to \\host\admin$\temp\'. If this     path is not accessible you should change it to use another share that the host local system account has write access to. By default, the path will have to be  changed on Windows 2000 systems
nasDevice - The NAS device to run the command on when using the NAS connect API protocol.

Responses\:
success - the command was executed successfully
failure - the command could not be executed

Extra Results\:
stdErr - the STDERR of the command
stdOut - the STDOUT of the command
6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.c56e79f7-ea23-434e-b8c9-40fbc3f05be0.prompt=PID\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.d0152a25-7066-4c73-9fb1-7d56666bbb12.prompt=Protocol\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.d9393f75-25d6-4133-ba83-f8c61ae9380b.prompt=Timeout\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.description=
This operation executes the kill command to terminate a process running on the remote host. 

Inputs\:
host -  The system to check.
username - The user to log into this system as.
password - The password to log in with.
PID - The PID to kill.
forceKill - If Yes, the process is terminated forcefully. Defaults to No.
port - Port number for connecting to the host.
protoco - The protocol used to run the command (can be one of ssh, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, local).
timeout - Time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete. Defaults to 90 seconds.
pty - If True, uses pty.
privateKeyFile - The absolute path to the private key file for remote host..
sasHost - The host we want to run the ROSH command on.
sasHostUsername - The username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost.
usernamePrompt - The prompt that when seen should send the username.
passwordPrompt - The prompt that when given should send the password.
outputPath - Network accessible path used by the operation to store temporary files. If not specified it points to \\host\admin$\temp\'. If this path is not accessible you should change it to use another share that the host local system account has write access to. By default, the path will have to be  changed on Windows 2000 systems.

Responses\:
success - kill command was executed successfully.
failure - Failed to execute the kill command.

Result\:
The return code of the kill command.

Note\:
The response for this operation will be set to success if the kill command returns success. In some cases, kill command might not kill the process and can still return success.
6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.e94d88ff-3851-4c9a-bf47-eb940c5f86c9.prompt=Enter host\: 6993d05a-a227-4e7d-ae54-2e7ca2700d65.eff4981a-b74d-4cf5-9694-7cdc22067e63.description=
Adds a flow variable into the local context (available to itself and child flows only)

Input Parameters\:
keyName - the name of the flow variable to use
myValue - the value to assign the flow variable

Responses\:
success - assigned the flow variable

Scriptlet Example\:
[$scriptletContext putGlobal\: $keyName, $myValue];
flow.name: Kill Process
